selfCitationGroup.citation: Gürol, B. 2024, Astron. Nachr., 345, e20240028. https://doi.org/10.1002/asna.20240028

titleGroup.title: HX Velorum: Ellipsoidal/Rotational Binary With β Cep Type Component
GüROL

affiliation.orgDiv: Department of Astronomy and Space Sciences

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: We present the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) light curve analysis of HX Velorum, located in the Southern Hemisphere, where one of the components is found for the first time to be a β$$ \beta $$ Cep (BCEP) type pulsator. The TESS observations of HX Velorum were published in a total of 6 sectors. Fourier analysis of the observations reveals that the frequencies can be divided into two categories, one of which is related to the orbital period and the other related to the β$$ \beta $$ Cep‐type pulsation. Its non‐eclipsing light curve was analyzed with the well‐known Wilson–Devinney code, and we obtained the geometric and physical parameters of the components using published radial velocity and light curve data by making some assumptions. We obtained plausible masses and radii of the primary and secondary components as M1=9.48±0.27M⊙$$ {M}_1=9.48\pm 0.27{M}_{\odot } $$, M2=5.92±0.17M⊙$$ {M}_2=5.92\pm 0.17{M}_{\odot } $$ and R1=3.93±0.04R⊙$$ {R}_1=3.93\pm 0.04{R}_{\odot } $$, R2=3.59±0.03R⊙$$ {R}_2=3.59\pm 0.03{R}_{\odot } $$, respectively. The obtained system's distance of ∼400$$ \sim 400 $$ pc is smaller than the Gaia distances found in the literature.

section.title: INTRODUCTION
section.p: Investigation of stellar structure and evolution of stars is based on precisely measured absolute parameters of stars. Light and radial velocity observations of eclipsing binaries offer us reliable masses and radii of components. For the best‐investigated eclipsing binaries, the precisions are obtained around ±0.02$$ \pm 0.02 $$ (Andersen 1991; Lee et al. 2020; Torres, Andersen, and Giménez 2010). Those obtained absolute parameters are widely used to improve theoretical stellar models and to determine the age of the components of eclipsing binary systems. Compared to low‐mass stars, the number of binary stars containing high‐mass (≳8M⊙$$ \gtrsim 8{M}_{\odot } $$) stars is quite low. There are often notable differences between the masses derived from eclipsing binaries and stellar evolution models, with the former masses being systematically smaller than the latter masses (Herrero et al. 1992; Tkachenko et al. 2020). The DEBCati catalogue of detached eclipsing binaries currently lists a total of 334 systems, among which only 23 examples have masses greater than 8M⊙$$ 8{M}_{\odot } $$ (Southworth 2015).

Thanks to satellite telescopes (Kepler, TESS, CoRot, etc.), we can obtain high‐quality data with long and systematic observations. We began to see that there were additional variations in most stars that we could not detect from ground‐based observations, for example, Antoci et al. (2019); Chen et al. (2022); Gaulme and Guzik (2019); Gürol (2023, 2024); Gürol et al. (2024); Kołaczek‐Szymański et al. (2021); Southworth and Bowman (2022); Zhou (2024). HX Velorum is such a system that was suspected to be a β$$ \beta $$ Cep type pulsator but could not be proven until this work.

β$$ \beta $$ Cep pulsators are generally considered to be early‐type B stars (B0–B2.5) with light and radial velocity variations on timescales of several hours (De Cat and Aerts 2002). These stars are massive non‐supergiant variables, and the pulsational variation is caused by low‐order pressure and gravity mode pulsations (Stankov and Handler 2005).

HX Vel (HD 74455, TIC 93997745, HR 3462, Rot 1375, V=5m.468$$ V={5}^m.468 $$, B=5m.288$$ B={5}^m.288 $$, α2000=08h42′16′′.19$$ {\alpha}_{2000}={08}^h{42}^{\prime }{16}^{\prime \prime }.19 $$, δ2000=−48o05′56′′.75$$ {\delta}_{2000}=-{48}^o{05}^{\prime }{56}^{\prime \prime }.75 $$) is classified as a Double or Multiple Star in the Simbad database, and the spectral type and distance of the system are given as B2/3 IV/V (Houk 1978) and 627.49 pc (Gaia Collaboration 2022), respectively. The system is listed in the Catalogue of Components of Double and Multiple Stars (Dommanget and Nys 1994) as the brighter component of the astrometric system.

The system was observed by Jerzykiewicz and Sterken (1977) for searching β$$ \beta $$ Cep type stars and found the period of variability to be 0.563±0.001$$ 0.563\pm 0.001 $$ days, with an amplitude in the b filter of 0.037±0.002$$ 0.037\pm 0.002 $$ mag. They concluded that the variability was caused by the ellipticity effect in the binary system, which has an orbital period twice the given value.

Later, the system was observed by Shobbrook (1981) as a candidate of β$$ \beta $$ Cep type variable, but because of the obtained period of 13.5 h (P=0.56205±0.00005$$ P=0.56205\pm 0.00005 $$ day), it was stated as an ellipsoidal variable. By using a least square frequency analysis of the observations, Shobbrook (1981) found a second period of about 0.44 days and concluded that its unambiguous identification is impossible. The amplitude of the variation was given as 0.0378±0.009$$ 0.0378\pm 0.009 $$ mag in the V filter by Shobbrook (1981).

In the observational study of the influence of close companions on the pulsations of β$$ \beta $$ Cep stars, Waelkens and Rufener (1983) classified the system as a close binary with an orbital period of 1.1242 days.

The first radial velocity observation and solution were given by Özkardeş et al. (2012) and found the system's mass ratio as q=m2/m1=0.599±0.052$$ q={m}_2/{m}_1=0.599\pm 0.052 $$, including the Keplerian orbital parameters as a1sini=0.0098±0.0003$$ {a}_1\mathrm{sini}=0.0098\pm 0.0003 $$ AU, a2sini=0.0164±0.0003$$ {a}_2\mathrm{sini}=0.0164\pm 0.0003 $$ AU, M1sin3i=1.19±0.07M⊙$$ {M}_1{\sin}^3\mathrm{i}=1.19\pm 0.07{\mathrm{M}}_{\odot } $$, and M2sin3i=0.71±0.04M⊙$$ {M}_2{\sin}^3\mathrm{i}=0.71\pm 0.04{\mathrm{M}}_{\odot } $$.

The most detailed study of the system was carried out by Blackford et al. (2019), and they obtained the absolute parameters of the components using photometric and spectroscopic observations. It is classified as a close binary system that does not show eclipses. By assuming the orbital inclination as i(deg)=26$$ i\left(\mathit{\deg}\right)=26 $$, Blackford et al. (2019) obtained the absolute parameters of the components, as given in Table 1. There are, however, a couple of potential issues with these parameters and vsini$$ v\mathrm{sini} $$ values found in the literature, as detailed below.

titleGroup.title: TABLE
Absolute parameters of HX Vel‐A obtained by Blackford et al. (2019).

section.p: Assuming that the rotations are synchronized with the orbital motion, Blackford et al. (2019) obtained the mean equatorial rotation speeds of the primary and secondary components as ∼223$$ \sim 223 $$ and ∼136$$ \sim 136 $$ km/s, respectively. The vsini$$ v\mathrm{sini} $$ values found in the literature are given as 285 km/s (Uesugi and Fukuda 1970) and 317 km/s (Głębocki and Gnaciński 2005), the latter of which is based on the value provided by Uesugi and Fukuda (1970) but corrected for systematic errors.

By using the orbital inclination given in Table 1, we can obtain the rotational velocities of the components as 650 and 723 km/s, respectively, which are higher than the breakup velocities, vcrit=(GM/R)1/2∼569$$ {v}_{crit}={\left( GM/R\right)}^{1/2}\sim 569 $$ and ∼577$$ \sim 577 $$ km/s for the primary and secondary components, and are accepted as nonphysical. Probably, this situation is caused by the binary nature that was not known in the 1970s. The given mean rotational velocities of B‐type stars are around 200–210 km/s (McNally 1965). Using the mean rotational velocity for B‐type stars as 205 km/s and assuming the rotations are synchronized with the orbital motion, we can obtain the radius of the primary component as 4.53 R⊙$$ {R}_{\odot } $$, which is a bit smaller than the given value in Table 1.

Using the light ratio L1/L2=0.62/0.29$$ {L}_1/{L}_2=0.62/0.29 $$ in the Hipparcos V filter given by Blackford et al. (2019), we can calculate the magnitude difference of the components as Δm=m1−m2=−0m.825$$ \Delta m={m}_1-{m}_2=-{0}^m.825 $$. Because we know the system's V magnitude is 5m.468$$ {5}^m.468 $$, we can find the primary and secondary magnitudes separately as m1=5m.911$$ {m}_1={5}^m.911 $$ and m2=6m.716$$ {m}_2={6}^m.716 $$, respectively. Taking the absolute magnitudes of stars corresponding to the temperatures of T1=25,000$$ {T}_1=25,000 $$ and T2=20,000$$ {T}_2=20,000 $$ K as −2M.932$$ -{2}^{\mathrm{M}}.932 $$ and −2M.128$$ -{2}^{\mathrm{M}}.128 $$ (Eker et al. 2020), and using the interstellar absorption as Av=0m.27$$ {A}_v={0}^m.27 $$, we can obtain the distance of the system as ∼518$$ \sim 518 $$ pc, which is nearly 231 pc different from the given value in Table 1.

According to the absolute parameters given in Table 1, the radius of the components is given as R1=(5.0±0.3)R⊙$$ {R}_1=\left(5.0\pm 0.3\right){R}_{\odot } $$ and R2=(3.1±0.2)R⊙$$ {R}_2=\left(3.1\pm 0.2\right){R}_{\odot } $$. The sum of the radii of the two components is 8.1R⊙$$ 8.1{R}_{\odot } $$, and it is only 2.8R⊙$$ 2.8{R}_{\odot } $$ (min distance 1.5–max distance 4.1 R⊙$$ {R}_{\odot } $$) smaller than the semimajor axis of the orbit, aR⊙$$ a\left({R}_{\odot}\right) $$. Because of this, the system is correctly classified as a close binary system, and the components are probably deformed by the tidal interaction. Since some systems with early‐type components are known to be in a semi‐detached configuration, for example, Eggen (1978); Leung and Schneider (1978); Polushina (2004), HX Vel may also be in this situation. Additionally, because of the proximity and temperature differences, there must be a reflection effect seen in the light curve of the system.

By using the absolute parameters given in Table 1, we obtained the surface potentials of the primary and secondary components as Ω1=2.951$$ {\Omega}_1=2.951 $$ and Ω2=3.442$$ {\Omega}_2=3.442 $$, respectively. Additionally, the inner and outer critical potentials can be calculated with the same data, which are obtained as Ωinner=3.118$$ {\Omega}_{\mathrm{inner}}=3.118 $$ and Ωouter=2.752$$ {\Omega}_{\mathrm{outer}}=2.752 $$, respectively. Because Ω1$$ {\Omega}_1 $$ is located between Ωinner$$ {\Omega}_{\mathrm{inner}} $$ and Ωouter$$ {\Omega}_{\mathrm{outer}} $$, the primary component is essentially in an over‐contact configuration, with the fill‐out factor found as Ωinner−Ω1/Ωinner−Ωouter=45.6%$$ \left[{\Omega}_{\mathrm{inner}}-{\Omega}_1\right]/\left[{\Omega}_{\mathrm{inner}}-{\Omega}_{\mathrm{outer}}\right]=45.6\% $$. At the same time, the secondary component seems to be in a detached configuration, which indicates that such a system cannot be possible.

Some eclipsing binaries with early‐type components of similar periods are GW Car (P=1d.1289$$ P={1}^d.1289 $$, B5, semi‐detached), published by Chochol et al. (2003); AU Pup (P=1d.1264$$ P={1}^d.1264 $$, A0, over‐contact), published by Leung and Schneider (1978); IM Mon (P=1d.1902$$ P={1}^d.1902 $$, B5, detached), published by Bakis et al. (2011); and FZ CMa (P=1d.2731$$ P={1}^d.2731 $$, B2IV, detached), published by Moffat et al. (1983). These examples show us that HX Vel can be a detached, semi‐detached, or over‐contact system. However, among them, only FZ CMa exhibits β$$ \beta $$ Cep/SPB type periodic variation in the light curve (Southworth and Bowman 2022). Because there is no example of pulsation‐like variation seen in over‐contact systems, we conclude that HX Vel is most probably a detached or semi‐detached system.

section.title: TESS DATA AND LIGHT ELEMENTS
section.p: The observations of HX Vel were made by the TESS (Ricker et al. 2015) across a total of 6 sectors (8, 9, 35, 36, 61, and 63), with each sector having approximately ∼27.4$$ \sim 27.4 $$ days of observations and nearly 2 min (SC: Short Cadence) exposure time. The TESS data are publicly available in the MAST (Barbara A. Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopesii) archive. In this study, we prefer to use the PDCSAP (pre‐search data conditioning) data because long‐term trends have been removed from the data using the so‐called Co‐trending Basis Vectors (CBVs). A total of 94,405 observations of the system were obtained, and the time span is nearly 1523 days. The system is classified as an eclipsing binary in the TESS Eclipsing Binary Catalogueiii (Prša et al. 2022), and the ephemeris is given as follows: 1 Min.I(BJD)=2458518.825570(0.006292)+1.12448505(0.000002992)×E$$ {\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\mathit{\operatorname{Min}}.I(BJD)& =2458518.825570(0.006292)\\ {}& \kern1em +1.12448505(0.000002992)\times E\end{array}} $$

In Figure 1, we plotted all observations phased with the ephemeris given by Prša et al. (2022) for Sector 63. Formally, the light curve can be interpreted as an eclipsing binary, like W UMa or β$$ \beta $$ Lyrae type systems. When looked at carefully, it is possible to see that there is an additional variation in the light curve. Because of this, we plotted consecutive light curves of the same data in Figure 2 to clearly see the additional small amplitude variation. Due to the large amount of data, we only plotted the first ten consecutive light curves in Figure 2.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Light curve of HX Vel obtained by TESS in Sector 63. Phase values obtained with the ephemeris given by Prša et al. (2022).

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Consecutive first ten phased light curves of HX Vel obtained by TESS in Sector 63. Magnitudes for consecutive sectors are shifted by adding 0.01 mag relative to the previous light curve. Phase values are obtained with the ephemeris given by Prša et al. (2022).

section.p: It can be clearly seen in Figure 2 that there is a small amplitude periodic variation superimposed on a high amplitude variation, which is caused by the rotation and/or ellipsoidal effect of the components. It is understood that the broadening seen in the light curve is caused by the small amplitude systematic variation.

Although there is no actual eclipse in the system using the observations, we obtained 113 primary and 116 secondary minima times. The minima times were calculated using the Minima27iv software published by Dr. Bob Nelson. We see that some of the calculated minima times are highly affected by the pulsational variation seen in the light curves. In Appendix Table A1, we present the calculated minima times and their errors. Using the calculated minima times, we obtained the observed‐minus‐calculated (O−C)$$ \left(O-C\right) $$ variation as shown in Figure 3, which indicates that the orbital ephemeris must be corrected. By applying a linear fit to the (O−C)$$ \left(O-C\right) $$ data, we obtained a new ephemeris for primary minima as follows: 2 Min.I(BJD)=2458518.836097(0.000583)+1.12447963(0.00000066)×E$$ {\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\mathit{\operatorname{Min}}.I(BJD)& =2458518.836097(0.000583)\\ {}& \kern1em +1.12447963(0.00000066)\times E\end{array}} $$

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: (O−C)$$ \left(O-C\right) $$ variation and linear fit of HX Vel system.

section.p: Essentially, the linear fit corrects only the main trend, and its correctness is based on the time span and number of data points used in the fit. In Figure 4, we plot the (O−C)II$$ \left(O-C\right) II $$ variation, which is obtained by using the new ephemeris given in Equation (2). As can be seen in Figure 3, there is extra variation, which is mostly observed in eccentric binary systems as apsidal motion. Blackford et al. (2019) mentioned that the best solution for the radial velocity is obtained with e≈0.04$$ e\approx 0.04 $$ and ω≈350o$$ \omega \approx {350}^o $$, making it possible to observe apsidal motion for HX Vel. In Figure 4, we see that the primary and secondary minima vary in opposite directions, which can be a sign of apsidal motion. However, we know that the time scale of the apsidal motion is much longer (Bulut and Demircan 2007; Rosu 2021) than the calculated period for this type of system.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Periodic variation seen in (O−C)II$$ \left(O-C\right) II $$ of HX Vel and a sinusoidal fit made by hand.

section.p: A sine fit was performed manually for the variation seen in Figure 4, and the period was found to be ∼155.3$$ \sim 155.3 $$ days with a semi‐amplitude of 0.01 days (14.4 min) for both minima. The plausible reason for this variation is the shifting of the minima due to small amplitude pulsational variation seen in the light curves.

section.title: LIGHT CURVE ANALYSIS
section.p: In Figure 5, we plotted the obtained light curves for different sectors, with gray points showing the individual data and black points showing the phase‐binned mean data obtained by averaging with a 0.001 phase interval. The broadening in the phase is probably caused by the used linear orbital ephemeris. As we see in Figure 4, it essentially changed periodically with ∼155.3$$ \sim 155.3 $$ days. Although phase‐binned points have been obtained, we can still see the small amplitude periodic variation related to the pulsation in Figure 5. Because of this, we prefer to use all the phase‐binned data for different sectors at the same time in the light curve analysis.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Light curves of HX Vel obtained for different sectors, including the phase‐binned mean data (black dots) obtained by averaging with 0.001 phase intervals. Magnitudes for consecutive sectors are shifted by adding 0.005 mag relative to the previous sector's data. Phase values are obtained with the ephemeris given in Equation (2).

section.p: In Table 2, we give the distances, spectral types, effective temperatures, and the methods used to obtain the data found for HX Vel in the literature. As can be seen, the distances and temperatures differ significantly from each other. This is likely due to the astrometric component and/or the binary nature of the system.

titleGroup.title: TABLE
Distance, spectral type, and temperatures given for HX Vel in the literature including the method of used.

section.p: According to the data given in Table 2, the median of distance and effective temperature (excluding the smallest one) were obtained as 754±377$$ 754\pm 377 $$ pc and 19820±5132$$ 19820\pm 5132 $$ K, respectively. The errors indicate that the obtained distance and temperature are not sufficiently small to make the right decision about the system's nature.

Because the system's radial velocity data is published by Blackford et al. (2019), we used it in the light curve analysis of the system. Using the published semi‐amplitudes of the primary and secondary components as K1=83.3±1.1$$ {K}_1=83.3\pm 1.1 $$ and K2=131.7±1.5$$ {K}_2=131.7\pm 1.5 $$ km s −1$$ {}^{-1} $$, the system's mass ratio is obtained as q=m2/m1=0.633±0.011$$ q={m}_2/{m}_1=0.633\pm 0.011 $$ and used as starting parameters in the light curve analysis.

The most important parameter for the HX Vel system seems to be the inclination of the orbit. This information can be easily obtained for eclipsing binaries. Since we cannot see an eclipse in the light curve of HX Vel, it is not possible to obtain the orbital inclination exactly, but it may be possible to make an estimate. The worst thing is that the mass of the system is extremely sensitive to the lower orbital inclinations with M1+M2sin3i$$ \left({M}_1+{M}_2\right){\sin}^3\mathrm{i} $$. Additionally, because the sizes of the components can be determined by measuring the contact times in the eclipsing binaries, this information cannot be obtained for HX Vel exactly either. For this reason, the solution of the HX Vel system can only be obtained by analogy with stars of the same spectral type found in the literature.

In Table 3, we calculated the mass of the components according to different orbital inclinations. As can be seen, for lower orbital inclinations, the mass of the components tends to be exceptionally large values. Since the mass of B1.5 type stars is given as ∼9M⊙$$ \sim 9{M}_{\odot } $$ by Eker et al. (2020), assuming the mass of the B1.5 type stars is correct, we can estimate the orbital inclination. If the orbital inclination is taken as i(deg)=25.4$$ i\left(\deg \right)=25.4 $$, the mass of the primary and secondary components is obtained as M1=9.00M⊙$$ {M}_1=9.00{M}_{\odot } $$ and M2=5.69M⊙$$ {M}_2=5.69{M}_{\odot } $$, respectively.

titleGroup.title: TABLE
Mass of the components according to the orbital inclination.

section.p: The Wilson and Devinney (Wilson 1979, 1990; Wilson and Devinney 1971; Wilson and Van Hamme 2014) code was used to solve the light curve of the HX Vel system. The subscripts 1 and 2 refer to the primary (hotter) and the secondary (cooler) components, respectively. Because the temperature is higher than 7200 K, we used the primary and secondary components' albedo and gravity darkening exponent at their reliable theoretical values of 1.0 and 1.0, respectively (Ruciński 1969; von Zeipel 1924). Limb darkening coefficients of both components (x1,2$$ {x}_{1,2} $$ and y1,2$$ {y}_{1,2} $$) were calculated by the Wilson–Devinney code using the Square Root law (LD = −3), where the values were calculated according to the input values of Teff$$ {T}_{\mathrm{eff}} $$, log g = 4.0, and [M/H] = −0.0026.

We prefer to solve the TESS light curves of HX Vel with the same parameters (i, q, a,T1$$ {T}_1 $$, T2$$ {T}_2 $$, R1$$ {R}_1 $$, R2$$ {R}_2 $$) given by Blackford et al. (2019) and compare them with the absolute parameters provided in the same work. Based on the parameters obtained from V filter data Blackford et al. (2019), the only variable parameter left is the luminosities of the components (L1$$ {L}_1 $$ and L2$$ {L}_2 $$) in the TESS filter. However, as argued before in Section 1, with the given parameters, the system cannot be an over‐contact + detached configuration. By assuming the configuration is semi‐detached, we can attempt to obtain a solution in Mode 4 (for semi‐detached systems where the primary component fills its Roche lobe). We try to obtain a light curve solution with this configuration, but we find that no reliable solution can be achieved. Subsequently, we attempt to solve the system in Mode 5 (for semi‐detached systems where the secondary component fills its Roche lobe, suitable for Algol‐type systems), but in the first run of the code, the configuration changes to detached type systems. Therefore, we select Mode 2 (for detached type systems) and allow the surface potentials of the primary and secondary components to vary for the light curve solution. We designate this solution as Solution#1, and the obtained geometric and absolute parameters are presented in Tables 4 and 5, respectively.

titleGroup.title: TABLE
The light and radial velocity curve solution of HX Vel using TESS observations.

note.p: Calculated by using components' temperature and radius.

section.p: Next, we try to obtain a solution for HX Vel using the same input parameters as those used in Solution#1, but changing the primary's temperature to Teff,1=20,000$$ {T}_{\mathrm{eff},1}=20,000 $$ K. This temperature is approximately the median value of the published data found in the literature. The obtained parameters for the light curve solution, which are assigned as Solution#2, are given in Tables 4 and 5 for comparison with the previous solution. Because the temperature of the primary component changed, all the other parameters, except the mass of the components, changed accordingly.

In the third solution, we changed the primary's effective temperature to be suitable for B1.5V type stars. It is obtained from the table of fundamental astrophysical parameters related to nearby main‐sequence stars published by Eker et al. (2020) as Teff,1=23,500$$ {T}_{\mathrm{eff},1}=23,500 $$ K. We also changed the orbital inclination to obtain a suitable mass for B1.5V type stars, resulting in i(deg)=25.38661$$ i\left(\deg \right)=25.38661 $$. The obtained parameters for the light curve solution, assigned as Solution#3, are given in Tables 4 and 5 for comparison with previous solutions.

With all solutions obtained after a coarse solution, we let the l3$$ {l}_3 $$ (third‐light) parameter be free because the system is located in a crowded region. However, after observing that it is going to have negative values, we do not use it as a free parameter. Additionally, we select the number of reflection parameters as nref = 3 with detailed reflection. The convergent solution was obtained with the adjustable parameters through iteration, until the corrections on the parameters became smaller than the corresponding standard deviations.

The observed and theoretical light and radial velocity curves, calculated with the final elements, are shown in Figure 6, including the three different fits to the observations. There is no noticeable difference between the different solutions. It seems that the light curve of HX Vel can be solved with quite different parameter sets.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: The observational (gray dots) and theoretical (black, cyan, and red line) light curves of HX Vel for all sectors (upper plot) and radial velocity solution (lower plot) for Solution#3.

section.p: In Figure 7, we plotted the Roche geometry of the components that are in a detached configuration with surface deformation due to the proximity effect. The parameters obtained from the light curve analysis are given in Table 5. Because the LC code does not provide the errors of the absolute parameters, we estimated them from the input parameters. The errors presented here correspond to the propagated errors of the input and calculated parameters.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Surface outline of HX Vel plotted by using Binary‐Maker 3 (Bradstreet and Steelman 2002).

section.p:
By taking Solution#3 as the most likely solution for HX Vel, and using the semi‐major axis and the mean fractional radii obtained from the light and radial velocity solution, we can find the radii of the components in solar units separately. The mean fractional radii of the components were calculated with the formula, rmean=rpole×rside×rback1/3$$ {r}_{\mathrm{mean}}={\left({r}_{pole}\times {r}_{\mathrm{side}}\times {r}_{\mathrm{back}}\right)}^{1/3} $$ as 0.34740±0.00022$$ 0.34740\pm 0.00022 $$ and 0.31730±0.00041$$ 0.31730\pm 0.00041 $$ for the primary and secondary components, respectively. Using those values, we can calculate the radii of the components as R1=a×r1,mean=(3.934±0.037)R⊙$$ {R}_1=a\times {r}_{1,\mathrm{mean}}=\left(3.934\pm 0.037\right){R}_{\odot } $$ and R2=a×r2,mean=(3.594±0.034)R⊙$$ {R}_2=a\times {r}_{2,\mathrm{mean}}=\left(3.594\pm 0.034\right){R}_{\odot } $$. The absolute parameters of Mbol1,2$$ {M}_{\mathrm{bol}1,2} $$ and L1,2$$ {L}_{1,2} $$ can be calculated using the well‐known Equations (3) and (4), respectively. 3 Mbol1,2=4m.74−5log(R1,2/R⊙−10logT1,2/T⊙$$ {M}_{\mathrm{bol}1,2}={4}^m.74-5\mathit{\log}\Big({R}_{1,2}/{\mathrm{R}}_{\odot }-10\mathit{\log}\left({T}_{1,2}/{\mathrm{T}}_{\odot}\right) $$
4 L1,2L⊙=R1,2/R⊙2T1,2/T⊙4$$ {L}_{1,2}\left({L}_{\odot}\right)={\left({R}_{1,2}/{\mathrm{R}}_{\odot}\right)}^2{\left({T}_{1,2}/{\mathrm{T}}_{\odot}\right)}^4 $$

Adopting T⊙=5772$$ {T}_{\odot }=5772 $$ K, the bolometric magnitudes are found to be Mbol,1=−4.322±0.186$$ {M}_{\mathrm{bol},1}=-4.322\pm 0.186 $$ and Mbol,2=−3.479±0.215$$ {M}_{\mathrm{bol},2}=-3.479\pm 0.215 $$, and luminosities L1=(4253.382±728.376)L⊙$$ {L}_1=\left(4253.382\pm 728.376\right){L}_{\odot } $$ and L2=(1957.233±388.343)L⊙$$ {L}_2=\left(1957.233\pm 388.343\right){L}_{\odot } $$ for the primary and secondary components, respectively.

Using the BCTESS−Teff$$ {BC}_{TESS}-{T}_{\mathrm{eff}} $$ relation given for main sequence stars by Eker and Bakış (2023), we can obtain the bolometric correction for the primary and secondary components as −2.437 and −2.050, respectively. Since the bolometric correction is obtainable, we can calculate the absolute magnitude of the components in the TESS filter separately by using the formula MTESS=Mbol−BCTESS$$ {M}_{\mathrm{TESS}}={M}_{\mathrm{bol}}-{BC}_{\mathrm{TESS}} $$, which gives us MTESS,pri=−1.884±0.187$$ {M}_{\mathrm{TESS},\mathrm{pri}}=-1.884\pm 0.187 $$ and MTESS,sec=−1.429±0.216$$ {M}_{\mathrm{TESS},\sec }=-1.429\pm 0.216 $$ for the primary and secondary components, respectively. The average E(B−V) color excess of the system is obtained as 0m.060$$ {0}^m.060 $$ by using the values given in the literature (Friedemann 1992; Megier et al. 2005; Savage et al. 1985). The interstellar extinction in the TESS filter can be obtained with the relation given by Eker and Bakış (2023) as A(TESS)=1.96×E(B−V)=0m.1164$$ A\left(\mathrm{TESS}\right)=1.96\times E\left(B-V\right)={0}^m.1164 $$. By using the system's magnitude as TESS=5m.697±0.004$$ \mathrm{TESS}={5}^m.697\pm 0.004 $$ and light ratios of L1/L2(TESS)=1.499±0.004$$ {L}_1/{L}_2\left(\mathrm{TESS}\right)=1.499\pm 0.004 $$, we can obtain the magnitudes of the primary and secondary components in the TESS filter as Tpri.=6m.252±0.006$$ {T}_{pri.}={6}^m.252\pm 0.006 $$ and Tsec.=6m.692±0.006$$ {T}_{\mathit{\sec}.}={6}^m.692\pm 0.006 $$, respectively. Using those values, we can calculate the distances of the primary and secondary components as 5 d1(pc)=10Tpri.−A(T)−MTESS,pri.+5/5=401.85±15.04$$ {d}_1(pc)={10}^{\left[\left({T}_{\mathrm{pri}.}-A(T)-{M}_{\mathrm{TESS},\mathrm{pri}.}+5\right)/5\right]}=401.85\pm 15.04 $$
6 d2(pc)=10Tsec.−A(T)−MTESS,sec.+5/5=398.90±17.27$$ {d}_2(pc)={10}^{\left[\left({T}_{\sec .}-A(T)-{M}_{\mathrm{TESS},\sec .}+5\right)/5\right]}=398.90\pm 17.27 $$

The distance to the system evaluated from the light curve solution is consistent with some of the values given in the literature (see Table 2), and it is nearly 230 pc different from the Gaia distance (d = 627.4871 pc, Gaia Collaboration (2022)). Because the system is located in a crowded region, the given TESS magnitude is probably contaminated by nearby stars, which causes the system to appear brighter than it is. A difference of only 0.1 mag in TESS magnitude results in the system being approximately 15 pc farther or closer to us.

By assuming that the component rotations are synchronized with the orbital motion, we can obtain the rotational velocities of the primary and secondary components as 177 and 162 km/s, respectively. It can be seen that these values are quite compatible with those given by Blackford et al. (2019), which are 223 and 136 km/s, respectively.

section.title: PULSATIONAL ANALYSIS
section.p: Because of the light curve solution obtained in the previous section, we first obtained the residuals of the fit to use in the frequency analysis. However, after this process, we still see light variation caused by the rotation and/or ellipsoidal effect of the components. The amplitude of this variation is around 0.003 mag, but in addition to this, we see additional irregularities in the residuals. These irregularities are probably caused by the shifting of the small amplitude periodic variation. Essentially, we observe this effect in the (O−C) analysis (see Figure 4) and in the light curve analysis (see Figure 5) conducted in the previous sections.

Because of this, we prefer to analyze TESS observations in the frequency domain without removing the orbital light variation. We expect two frequencies related to the orbital variation (due to the different depths of the primary and secondary minima) and the frequency or frequencies related to the small amplitude variation seen in the light curves (see Figure 2). Since the time span between different sectors sometimes reaches 700 days, we prefer to analyze the data separately for each sector. In Figure 8, we plotted the amplitude spectrum of the Fourier analysis obtained by using Period04 (Lenz and Breger 2005), where two main frequencies can be seen. In Figure 9, we plotted the same figures for a restricted frequency range to clearly see the additional frequencies obtained in this analysis. In this work, we use an iterative pre‐whitening method to extract the frequencies of the amplitude spectrum with a signal‐to‐noise ratio (SNR) >4.0 from the lightcurve, as proposed by Breger et al. (1993). These frequencies are located in a region of relatively high frequencies with lower amplitudes. Like the two frequencies obtained for orbital variation, these frequencies are probably related to each other too.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Amplitude spectrum of the rotational and pulsational variation obtained for HX Vel system for all sectors. Generated by the Period04 in the frequency domain. The red solid line is four times of the noise spectrum.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Amplitude spectrum of the pulsational variation obtained for HX Vel system for all sectors which restricted at 11<fd−1<14$$ 11<f\left({d}^{-1}\right)<14 $$ frequencies. Generated by the Period04 in the frequency domain. The red solid line is four times of the noise spectrum.

section.p: As can be seen, there are two distinct periodic variations, one of which belongs to the large amplitude variation (rotational and/or ellipsoidal), and the second one belongs to the small amplitude pulsation. In Figure 10, we plotted a portion of Sector 8 observations, including the Fourier fit and residuals of the fit. Because we do not use normalized data in the Fourier analysis, the obtained extra frequencies are probably related to the instrumental variation.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Part of Fourier fit (red line) to the Sector 8 observations (black dots) and residuals of the fit which are shifted vertically (black points).

section.p: We found that the frequencies obtained for all sectors are quite stable. The results for different sectors are given in the Appendix Table B1, including frequency, amplitude, phase, S/N, period, Porb/P$$ {P}_{\mathrm{orb}}/P $$, and possible combinations and interpretations of frequencies. In the last column of Table B1, we marked the possible linear combinations of frequency following the method described in Zhang et al. (2020); Zhang et al. (2019) in the form of fi=mfj±nfk$$ {f}_i={mf}_j\pm {nf}_k $$, where m$$ m $$ and n$$ n $$ are integers less than 3 (Kurtz et al. 2015). The average of selected frequencies and amplitudes with standard errors is given in Table 6. Two of them clearly depend on the orbital frequency (forb=0.8893002d−1$$ {f}_{\mathrm{orb}}=0.8893002{d}^{-1} $$). The other three frequencies indicated as BCEP# in Table 6 are thought to be directly related to the β$$ \beta $$ Cep type pulsation.

titleGroup.title: TABLE
The average and standard errors of frequencies, and amplitudes found in all sectors.

section.p: Because of the physical parameters of the components of HX Vel obtained in the previous section, we think that we can classify the type of pulsator. In Figure 11, we plotted the Hertzsprung–Russell diagram (HRD) for stars, including the positions of the primary and secondary components obtained for different solutions. As can be seen in Figure 11, for all solutions, both components are in a region of β$$ \beta $$ Cep/SPB type pulsators. Additionally, in Figure 11, we plotted the evolutionary tracks of the components for [Fe/H]=−0.0026$$ \left[ Fe/H\right]=-0.0026 $$ (Gaia Collaboration 2022) composition using the MISTv database (Choi et al. 2016; Dotter 2016; Paxton et al. 2011, 2013, 2015). We obtained the age of the stars as log t = 6.85 (∼7$$ \sim 7 $$ Myr) by using the same isochrones obtained from the MIST database.

figure.title: FIGURE
figure.caption: Position of the primary and secondary component of HX Vel on HR diagram (blue and red points with different symbols, respectively). Data of confirmed and candidate BCEPs obtained from Stankov and Handler (2005). ZAMS, TAMS and the boundaries of the theoretical β$$ \beta $$ Cephei instability strip obtained from Pamyatnykh (1999). Isochrones obtained for [Fe/H]=−0.0026$$ \left[ Fe/H\right]=-0.0026 $$ (Gaia Collaboration 2022) using MIST database (Choi et al. 2016; Dotter 2016; Paxton et al. 2011, 2013, 2015).

section.p: Because the dynamical masses of Solution#3 are closer to the evolutionary masses from the MIST models at the given metallicity from the Gaia catalogue, we accept it as the better solution of the three. As can be seen, both components (blue and red points in Figure 11) are located in the β$$ \beta $$ Cep instability strip. The location of the components shows us that one of the components in HX Vel is a β$$ \beta $$ Cep type pulsator. HX Vel was classified as a candidate β$$ \beta $$ Cep pulsator by Stankov and Handler (2005), but its confirmation was made for the first time in this study.

We obtained at least three frequencies belonging to the β$$ \beta $$ Cephei type pulsation at fBCEP1=12.4688267d−1$$ {f}_{\mathrm{BCEP}1}=12.4688267{d}^{-1} $$, fBCEP2=12.7774055d−1$$ {f}_{\mathrm{BCEP}2}=12.7774055{d}^{-1} $$ and fBCEP3=7.916174d−1$$ {f}_{\mathrm{BCEP}3}=7.916174{d}^{-1} $$. The corresponding pulsation periods are 0.0802, 0.07826, and 0.1263 days, respectively, which are a bit longer than the shortest period (0.0667 days) given in the catalogues for β$$ \beta $$ Cep type pulsators (Stankov and Handler 2005). According to the obtained pulsation periods, the system can be classified as a multiperiodic pulsator.

Galactic coordinates combined with the calculated distance suggest that the system is located in the young disk population. The binary model yields a mean density of ρ1=0.156ρ⊙$$ {\rho}_1=0.156{\rho}_{\odot } $$ and ρ2=0.128ρ⊙$$ {\rho}_2=0.128{\rho}_{\odot } $$ for the primary and secondary components, respectively. Using the mean fBECP1$$ {f}_{BECP1} $$ frequency and the relation (Q=Ppulsρ/ρ⊙$$ Q={P}_{\mathrm{puls}}\sqrt{\rho /{\rho}_{\odot }} $$) given for the pulsation constant, we obtained pulsation constants of Q1=0.032$$ {Q}_1=0.032 $$ and Q2=0.029$$ {Q}_2=0.029 $$ days for the primary and secondary components, respectively. We see that both pulsation constants are in the vicinity of a sharp peak located at Q = 0.033 day and below the upper limit of Q = 0.06 day given for confirmed β$$ \beta $$ Cephei type stars by Stankov and Handler (2005). Because the pulsational period is located between 1 and 12 h, according to the given boundary for β$$ \beta $$ Cep type stars by Aerts, Christensen‐Dalsgaard, and Kurtz (2010), the pulsation type is assigned as low‐order pressure (p) mode.

section.title: CONCLUSIONS
section.p: In this work, we proved for the first time that one of the components of HX Velorum essentially shows β$$ \beta $$ Cep type pulsation. We obtained physical and geometrical parameters of the components of HX Vel by making an approximation for the orbital inclination. We see that both components are located remarkably close to the border of the β$$ \beta $$ Cep instability strip in the HRD (Figure 11). Since no eclipse occurs, this makes it somewhat difficult to classify which component is essentially pulsating.

The orbital ephemeris of the system is refined by using all the primary and secondary minima times obtained in this work. We see that both primary and secondary minima times are periodically changing with the same period (∼155.3$$ \sim 155.3 $$ days) and amplitude (∼0.01$$ \sim 0.01 $$ mag). This variation is caused by the shifting of the small amplitude pulsational variation.

The system's configuration is obtained as a detached close binary system in which the components do not yet fill their inner Roche lobes. The Roche geometry of the components shows that they are slightly deformed due to tidal interaction. It is confirmed that the main light variation of the system is caused by the rotation and orbital motion of the ellipsoidal components. The obtained rotational velocities of the primary and secondary components, 177 and 162 km/s, respectively, are very close to the spectrally obtained values given by Blackford et al. (2019), which are 223 and 136 km/s, and can be taken as confirmation of the light curve solution made in this work.

The obtained pulsation constants, Q1=0.032$$ {Q}_1=0.032 $$ days and Q2=0.029$$ {Q}_2=0.029 $$ days for the primary and secondary components, respectively, are nearly the same as the sharp peak (Q = 0.033 days) in the histogram obtained for confirmed β$$ \beta $$ Cep type stars by Stankov and Handler (2005), which corresponds to the value for radial fundamental mode pulsation. Considering the limit of the pulsational period for β$$ \beta $$ Cep type stars given by Aerts, Christensen‐Dalsgaard, and Kurtz (2010), we conclude that the pulsation is a low‐order pressure (p) mode.

The distance of the system is obtained as ∼400$$ \sim 400 $$ pc, and it is quite different from some distances given in the literature (see Table 2). However, some distances are consistent with the values obtained in this work. With this distance, the system cannot be a member of the open cluster IC 2395 (d = 705 pc) (Clariá et al. 2003), contrary to what Blackford et al. (2019) found.

Although the absolute and geometric parameters of the system were obtained by making an approximation, we believe that the parameters obtained in this work can be used in theoretical studies related to the β$$ \beta $$ Cep type pulsators.

section.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
section.p: We thank to the anonymous referee for very important comments and suggestions that greatly improved the quality of this paper. This research has made use of VizieR the Simbad database, operated at CDS, Strasbourg, France, and NASA's Astrophysics Data System Abstract Service. This work has made use of data from the European Space Agency (ESA) mission Gaia (https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia), processed by the Gaia Data Processing and Analysis Consortium (DPACvi). Funding for the DPAC has been provided by national institutions, in particular the institutions participating in the Gaia Multilateral Agreement. The TESS data presented in this paper were obtained from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST). Funding for the TESS mission is provided by the NASA Explorer Program.
All the figures were generated by using a free‐ware software GNUPLOTvii.

section.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT
section.p: The authors declare no potential conflict of interests.

Wright, C. O., M. P. Egan, K. E. Kraemer, and S. D. Price. 2003. “The Tycho‐2 Spectral Type Catalog.” Astronomical Journal 125, no. 1: 359–363.

Zhang, X., X. Chen, H. Zhang, J. Fu, and Y. Li. 2020. “A Pre‐Main‐Sequence γ Dor‐δ Sct Hybrid with Extremely Slow Internal Rotation in a Short‐Period Eclipsing Binary KIC 9850387 Revealed by Asteroseismology.” Astrophysical Journal 895, no. 2: 124.

Zhang, X. B., K. Wang, X. H. Chen, C. Q. Luo, and C. G. Zhang. 2019. “Discovery and Seismic Analysis of an EL CVn‐type Binary with Hybrid δ Sct‐γ Dor Pulsations.” Astrophysical Journal 884, no. 2: 165.
Zhou, A.‐. Y. 2024. “Resolving the Pulsation Contents of 13 δ Scuti Stars with TESS and K2.” New Astronomy 111: 102235.

titleGroup.title: APPENDIX
MINIMA TIMES OBTAINED BY USING TESS OBSERVATIONS

section.p: In this appendix, we list the minima times obtained from TESS data used in the (O−C) analysis. The minima times were obtained using Minima27 software by selecting different calculation methods.

titleGroup.title: TABLE
The calculated minima times and errors obtained using TESS observations of HX Vel.

note.p: Note: We list the sequence of the obtained minima (No), type of minima (I for primary and II for secondary), and Barycentric Julian Day as BJD.

section.p: In this appendix, we list the Fourier analysis results obtained for the HX Vel system using the Period04 (Lenz and Breger 2005) software. We include all frequencies obtained with a signal‐to‐noise ratio (SNR) >4.0, along with amplitude, phase, period, and the combinations related to the frequencies.

titleGroup.title: TABLE
Significant frequencies obtained for HX Vel.
